notes.title: Legal Notice

notes.text: Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code.
notes.title: Risk evaluation

notes.text: Commercial Facilities, Critical Manufacturing, Energy
notes.title: Critical infrastructure sectors

notes.text: Worldwide
notes.title: Countries/areas deployed

notes.text: France
notes.title: Company headquarters location

notes.text: CISA recommends users take defensive measures to minimize the risk of exploitation of this vulnerability, such as:
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Minimize network exposure for all control system devices and/or systems, ensuring they are not accessible from the internet.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Locate control system networks and remote devices behind firewalls and isolating them from business networks.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: When remote access is required, use more secure methods, such as Virtual Private Networks (VPNs), recognizing VPNs may have vulnerabilities and should be updated to the most current version available. Also recognize VPN is only as secure as the connected devices.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA reminds organizations to perform proper impact analysis and risk assessment prior to deploying defensive measures.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA also provides a section for control systems security recommended practices on the ICS webpage on cisa.gov/ics. Several CISA products detailing cyber defense best practices are available for reading and download, including Improving Industrial Control Systems Cybersecurity with Defense-in-Depth Strategies.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA encourages organizations to implement recommended cybersecurity strategies for proactive defense of ICS assets.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Additional mitigation guidance and recommended practices are publicly available on the ICS webpage at cisa.gov/ics in the technical information paper, ICS-TIP-12-146-01B--Targeted Cyber Intrusion Detection and Mitigation Strategies.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Organizations observing suspected malicious activity should follow established internal procedures and report findings to CISA for tracking and correlation against other incidents.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA also recommends users take the following measures to protect themselves from social engineering attacks:
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Do not click web links or open attachments in unsolicited email messages.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Refer to Recognizing and Avoiding Email Scams for more information on avoiding email scams.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Refer to Avoiding Social Engineering and Phishing Attacks for more information on social engineering attacks.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: No known public exploitation specifically targeting this vulnerability has been reported to CISA at this time. This vulnerability is not exploitable remotely.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

document.title: Schneider Electric EcoStruxure Power Build Rapsody

product.name: Schneider Electric EcoStruxure Power Build Rapsody: <=v2.7.12_FR

notes.text: A CWE-121 Stack-based Buffer Overflow vulnerability exists that could cause local attackers being able to exploit these issues to potentially execute arbitrary code while the end user opens a malicious project file (SSD file) provided by the attacker.
notes.title: Vulnerability Summary

remediations.details: Schneider Electric has identified the following specific workarounds and mitigations users can apply to reduce risk:
EcoStruxure Power Build Rapsody: Version v2.8.2 FR of EcoStruxure Power Build Rapsody includes a fix for this vulnerability and is available for download.
Store the project files in a secure storage and restrict the access to only trusted users.
When exchanging files over the network, use secure communication protocols.
Only open project files received from a trusted source.
Compute a hash of the project files and regularly check the consistency of this hash to verify the integrity before usage.
Harden the workstation running EcoStruxure Power Build Rapsody
Schneider Electric strongly recommends the following industry cybersecurity best practices:
Locate control and safety system networks and remote devices behind firewalls and isolate them from the business network.
Install physical controls so no unauthorized personnel can access your industrial control and safety systems, components, peripheral equipment, and networks.
Place all controllers in locked cabinets and never leave them in the "Program" mode.
Never connect programming software to any network other than the network for the devices that it is intended.
Scan all methods of mobile data exchange with the isolated network such as CDs, USB drives, etc. before use in the terminals or any node connected to these networks.
Never allow laptops that have connected to any other network besides the intended network to connect to the safety or control networks without proper sanitation.
Minimize network exposure for all control system devices and systems, and ensure that they are not accessible from the Internet.

When remote access is required, use secure methods, such as virtual private networks (VPNs). Recognize that VPNs may have vulnerabilities and should be updated to the most current version available. Also, understand that VPNs are only as secure as the connected devices.
For more information, see Schneider Electric security notification SEVD-2025-133-03.
